titleStmt.title: Biyat Harran
SHAWI Corpus
titleStmt.funder: Funded by the FWF Austrian Science Fund under the number P 33574

publicationStmt.distributor: Austrian Center for Digital Humanities and Cultural Heritage

prefixDef.p: Private URIs using the teiCorpusHeader prefix are pointers to any element in the SHAWI teiCorpus document.
Private URIs using the share prefix are pointers to audio file residing on the SHAWI network share.
Private URIs using the geo prefix are pointers to the xml:id attribute on a place element in VICAV Geodata list.
Private URIs using the zotid prefix are pointers to the xml:id attribute on a biblStruct element in the TEI export of the VICAV Zotero Group library.

spanGrp.span: biyāt is, let’s say, if a woman wants to have children, but, let’s say, she (always) loses them, they die (before birth).
Those who go (for biyāt) are those whose children die. Those who miscarry (lit. whose children go), the one who, let’s say, has a problem.
These go to the sheikh, to a sheikh who makes the biyāt .Let’s say one who has no (kids) tells the sheikh (her problem).
He says, “Give me a piece from your cloth!” What means ʕabag? ʕabag is what is worn, garment, what is worn all the time, I mean things that she has used.
Let’s say a headcloth or a scarf or a piece of dress.
And whatever you are happy to give (viz. money), you wrap into them; only how much you really give from your heart I mean.
There is not a certain amount necessary. He wraps them in the thingy, in the biyāt; the sheikh puts them inside and sleeps over it with good intentions.
Some of them also do it (by bringing it) to the sheikh’s wife who puts it secretly under the sheikh’s head.
Then he says “Hey, I dreamt of this and that.” He wakes up in the morning and says “I dreamt of the woman so-and-so.”
There is also something which puts it into his mind. I mean, the sheikh, now our sheikhs here also do the biyāt, the thingy. But any honest person can do the biyāt.
I mean not necessarily the sheikh. Any honest person can also do the biyāt because we have Islam here and therefore the mibīt (leaving things overnight at the sheikh) exists.
I mean, what is the mibīt? It is to take the thing... Let’s say, how do they call it in Turkish, let’s say, to do something [...] like consultation.
